G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, as it involves a request for modification of custody of a minor child in Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, as it involves a request for modification of custody of a minor child in Massachusetts.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: A parenting schedule that imposes caregiving responsibilities on a 12-year-old child or exposes her to safety risks is not consistent with her best interests.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss parenting schedules, the assignment of caregiving responsibilities to a 12‑year‑old, or safety risks arising from such a schedule. Its focus is on custody (physical vs. legal) and relocation to Greece under a “real advantage”/best‑interests analysis. Nothing in the holding or reasoning addresses, much less establishes a rule about, the impropriety of placing caregiving burdens on a child or exposing her to safety risks through a parenting plan.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Harmon v. Harmon*, 394 Mass. 223 (1985).proposition: A parenting schedule that imposes caregiving responsibilities on a 12-year-old child or exposes her to safety risks is not consistent with her best interests.
*Harmon v. Harmon*, 394 Mass. 223 (1985).support_reasoning: This opinion is a civil procedural case about appeals from the Appellate Division and retransfer to the Superior Court under G.L. c. 231, § 102C. It does not discuss child custody, parenting schedules, caregiving responsibilities of a 12‑year‑old, or best‑interests-of-the-child standards. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the proposed parenting‑schedule proposition.
*Harmon v. Harmon*, 394 Mass. 223 (1985).relevant_excerpt: We have stated that a decision of the Appellate Division is not a final one when retrial is available in the Superior Court under G. L. c. 231, § 102C. See, e.g., Greenhouse, Inc. v. Trans World Airlines, Inc., ante 60, 61 (1985); Locke v. Slater, 387 Mass. 682, 684 (1982); Pupillo v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 381 Mass. 714, 715 (1980). That is exactly the case here.

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts courts hold that the paramount goal in custody matters is the health, safety, and welfare of the child.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard for custody as the “best interests of the child” and cites cases and a statute listing factors related to the child’s health and welfare, but it does not expressly articulate the overarching formulation that the paramount goal is the child’s health, safety, and welfare. The closest language emphasizes best interests and consideration of effects on the child’s health, but that is not quite the same as the specific proposition claimed. Thus the case is consistent with, but does not clearly state or establish, the quoted formulation as a rule.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is ‘best for the child’…. However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts hold that the paramount goal in custody matters is the health, safety, and welfare of the child.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reiterates that in removal cases under G.L. c. 208, § 30, the statutory phrase "upon cause shown" means that removal must be in the "best interests" of the child, and it frames the entire analysis around what serves the children’s welfare. While the case does not use the exact phrasing "paramount goal" or explicitly list "health" and "safety," it clearly affirms that the controlling standard in such custody/relocation disputes is the child’s best interests, which encompasses the child’s welfare. Thus it provides reasonable support for the proposition, though not in those exact words.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that "[a] minor child of divorced parents ... shall not ... be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth ... without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders." "The words 'upon cause shown' mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child." Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), citing Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). ... "[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question." Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000).

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Plaintiff’s requested modification is consistent with the minor child’s best interests.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that the mother’s requested relocation and maintenance of her primary physical custody are in the child’s best interests. The Appeals Court reverses the Probate Court, finding no material and substantial change justifying a custody transfer, and concluding that the mother has a good, sincere reason to move that provides a real advantage and improves both her and the child’s quality of life. It orders that custody remain with the mother and that she may relocate with the child, explicitly based on best‑interests analysis.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
“There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements… To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker…

Based on this record, ‘[a] remand for findings of fact to support the judge’s order is unnecessary, because the evidence, weighed under the relevant factors… convincingly establishes that the plaintiff’s request should have been allowed.’ … We remand for the entry of a judgment that the custody of the parties’ minor child remain with the mother, [and] that she may relocate with the child to Rhode Island…”

*Allen v. Allen*, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 295.proposition: Plaintiff’s requested modification is consistent with the minor child’s best interests.
*Allen v. Allen*, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 295.support_reasoning: The opinion in Allen v. Allen is a Land Court/title dispute between adult siblings over real property based on competing deeds and recording/acknowledgment issues. It does not involve family law, custody, modification proceedings, or any analysis of a minor child’s best interests. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition that a plaintiff’s requested modification is consistent with a minor child’s best interests.
*Allen v. Allen*, 86 Mass. App. Ct. 295.relevant_excerpt: This case concerns competing claims between adult siblings for the ownership of the house formerly owned by their now-deceased parents... Following a jury-waived trial, a judge of the Land Court determined that, because the acknowledgment of the July deed was defective, its recording did not give constructive notice to Deborah of the conveyance and the deed was not enforceable against her.
